all_changes_deployed.description: True if all of an Action's contents have been deployed

code.description: The source code of the action

deploy.description: If set to true, it will deploy the action on every change

status.description: The build status of this action

block.description: The list of third party npm modules, and their versions, that this action depends on
The list of secrets that are included in an action or a version of an action
The list of triggers that this action supports. At this time, an action can only target a single trigger at a time

Actions are secure, tenant-specific, versioned functions written in Node.
js that execute at certain points during the Auth0 runtime. 

Actions are used to customize and extend Auth0's capabilities with custom logic.

page_background.description: String, Hexadecimal. Primary button background color.

primary.description: String, Hexadecimal. Background color of login pages.

block.description: Configuration settings for colors for branding

With Auth0, you can setting logo, color to maintain a consistent service brand. 
This resource allows you to manage a branding within your Auth0 tenant.

allowed_logout_urls.description: URLs that Auth0 may redirect to after logout

allowed_origins.description: URLs that represent valid origins for cross-origin resource sharing. By default, all your callback URLs will be allowed

app_type.description: Type of application the client represents. Options include `native`, `spa`, `regular_web`, `non_interactive`, `rms`, `box`, `cloudbees`, `concur`, `dropbox`, `mscrm`, `echosign`, `egnyte`, `newrelic`, `office365`, `salesforce`, `sentry`, `sharepoint`, `slack`, `springcm`, `zendesk`, `zoom`

callbacks.description: RLs that Auth0 may call back to after a user authenticates for the client. Make sure to specify the protocol (https://) otherwise the callback may fail in some cases. With the exception of custom URI schemes for native clients, all callbacks should use protocol https://

client_metadata.description: Metadata associated with the client, in the form of an object with string values (max 255 chars). Maximum of 10 metadata properties allowed. Field names (max 255 chars) are alphanumeric and may only include the following special characters: :,-+=_*?"/\()<>@ [Tab] [Space]

client_secret.description: Secret for the client; keep this private

client_secret_rotation_trigger.description: We recommend leaving the `client_secret` parameter unspecified to allow the generation of a safe secret

cross_origin_auth.description: Indicates whether or not the client can be used to make cross-origin authentication requests

cross_origin_loc.description: URL for the location on your site where the cross-origin verification takes place for the cross-origin auth flow. Used when performing auth in your own domain instead of through the Auth0-hosted login page

custom_login_page.description: Content of the custom login page

custom_login_page_on.description: Indicates whether or not a custom login page is to be used

description.description: Description of the purpose of the client (Max length = 140 characters)

encryption_key.description: Encryption used for WsFed responses with this client

grant_types.description: Types of grants that this client is authorized to use

initiate_login_uri.description: Initiate login uri, must be https

is_first_party.description: Indicates whether or not this client is a first-party client

is_token_endpoint_ip_header_trusted.description: Indicates whether or not the token endpoint IP header is trusted

logo_uri.description: URL of the logo for the client. Recommended size is 150px x 150px. If none is set, the default badge for the application type will be shown

oidc_conformant.description: Indicates whether or not this client will conform to strict OIDC specifications

organization_require_behavior.description: Specifies what type of prompt to use when your application requires that users select their organization. Only applicable when ORG_USAGE is require. Options include: `no_prompt`, `pre_login_prompt`

organization_usage.description: Dictates whether your application can support users logging into an organization. Options include: `deny`, `allow`, `require`

sso.description: Applies only to SSO clients and determines whether Auth0 will handle Single Sign On (true) or whether the Identity Provider will (false)

sso_disabled.description: Indicates whether or not SSO is disabled

token_endpoint_auth_method.description: Defines the requested authentication method for the token endpoint. Options include `none` (public client without a client secret), `client_secret_post` (client uses HTTP POST parameters), `client_secret_basic` (client uses HTTP Basic)

web_origins.description: URLs that represent valid web origins for use with web message response mode

audience.description: Audience of the SAML Assertion. Default will be the Issuer on SAMLRequest

authn_context_class_ref.description: Class reference of the authentication context

binding.description: Protocol binding used for SAML logout responses

create_upn_claim.description: Indicates whether or not a UPN claim should be created

destination.description: Destination of the SAML Response. If not specified, it will be `AssertionConsumerUrl` of SAMLRequest or `CallbackURL` if there was no SAMLRequest

digest_algorithm.description: Algorithm used to calculate the digest of the SAML Assertion or response. Options include `sha1` (default) and `sha256`

include_attribute_name_format.description: Indicates whether or not we should infer the NameFormat based on the attribute name. If set to false, the attribute NameFormat is not set in the assertion

lifetime_in_seconds.description: Number of seconds during which the token is valid

map_identities.description: Indicates whether or not to add additional identity information in the token, such as the provider used and the `access_token`, if available

map_unknown_claims_as_is.description: Indicates whether or not to add a prefix of `http://schema.auth0.com` to any claims that are not mapped to the common profile when passed through in the output assertion

mappings.description: Mappings between the Auth0 user profile property name (`name`) and the output attributes on the SAML attribute in the assertion (`value`)

name_identifier_probes.description: Attributes that can be used for Subject/NameID. Auth0 will try each of the attributes of this array in order and use the first value it finds

passthrough_claims_with_no_mapping.description: Indicates whether or not to passthrough claims that are not mapped to the common profile in the output assertion

recipient.description: Recipient of the SAML Assertion (SubjectConfirmationData). Default is AssertionConsumerUrl on SAMLRequest or Callback URL if no SAMLRequest was sent

sign_response.description: Indicates whether or not the SAML Response should be signed instead of the SAML Assertion

signature_algorithm.description: Algorithm used to sign the SAML Assertion or response. Options include `rsa-sha1` (default) and `rsa-sha256`

signing_cert.description: Optionally indicates the public key certificate used to validate SAML requests. If set, SAML requests will be required to be signed. A sample value would be `-----BEGIN PUBLIC KEY-----...-----END PUBLIC KEY-----`

callback.description: Service provider's Single Logout Service URL, to which Auth0 will send logout requests and responses

slo_enabled.description: Indicates whether or not Auth0 should notify service providers of session termination

block.description: Configuration settings for logout
Configuration settings for a SAML add-on
Configuration settings for add-ons for this client

lifetime_in_seconds.description: Number of seconds during which the JWT will be valid

secret_encoded.description: Indicates whether or not the client secret is base64 encoded

block.description: Configuration settings for the JWTs issued for this client
Android native app configuration
iOS native app configuration
Additional configuration for native mobile apps.

expiration_type.description: Refresh token expiration types, one of: `expiring`, `non-expiring`

idle_token_lifetime.description: Period (in seconds) for which refresh tokens will remain valid without use

infinite_idle_token_lifetime.description: Prevents tokens from expiring without use when `true` (takes precedence over `idle_token_lifetime` values)

infinite_token_lifetime.description: Prevents tokens from having a set lifetime when true (takes precedence over token_lifetime values)

leeway.description: Period in seconds where the previous refresh token can be exchanged without triggering breach detection

rotation_type.description: Refresh token rotation types, one of: `rotating`, `non-rotating`

token_lifetime.description: Period (in seconds) for which refresh tokens will remain valid

block.description: Configuration settings for the refresh tokens issued for this client

With this resource, you can set up applications that use Auth0 for authentication and configure 
allowed callback URLs and secrets for these applications. Depending on your plan, you may also configure add-ons to allow 
your application to call another application's API (such as Firebase and AWS) on behalf of an authenticated user.

Auth0 uses various grant types, 
or methods by which you grant limited access to your resources to another entity without exposing credentials. 
The OAuth 2.0 protocol supports several types of grants, which allow different types of access. 
This resource allows you to create and manage client grants used with configured Auth0 clients.

enabled_clients.description: IDs of the clients for which the connection is enabled

is_domain_connection.description: Indicates whether or not the connection is domain level

realms.description: Defines the realms for which the connection will be used (i.e., email domains). If not specified, the connection name is added as the realm

strategy.description: Type of the connection, which indicates the identity provider. Options include `ad`, `adfs`, `amazon`, `apple`, `dropbox`, `bitbucket`, `aol`,`auth0-adldap`, `auth0-oidc`, `auth0`, `baidu`, `bitly`,`box`, `custom`, `daccount`, `dwolla`, `email`,`evernote-sandbox`, `evernote`, `exact`, `facebook`,`fitbit`, `flickr`, `github`, `google-apps`,`google-oauth2`, `guardian`, `instagram`, `ip`, `linkedin`,`miicard`, `oauth1`, `oauth2`, `office365`, `oidc`, `paypal`,`paypal-sandbox`, `pingfederate`, `planningcenter`,`renren`, `salesforce-community`, `salesforce-sandbox`,`salesforce`, `samlp`, `sharepoint`, `shopify`, `sms`,`soundcloud`, `thecity-sandbox`, `thecity`,`thirtysevensignals`, `twitter`, `untappd`, `vkontakte`,`waad`, `weibo`, `windowslive`, `wordpress`, `yahoo`,`yammer`, `yandex`, `line`

brute_force_protection.description: Indicates whether or not to enable brute force protection, which will limit the number of signups and failed logins from a suspicious IP address

configuration.description: A case-sensitive map of key value pairs used as configuration variables for the `custom_script`

custom_scripts.description: Custom database action scripts. For more information, read [Custom Database Action Script Templates](https://auth0.com/docs/connections/database/custom-db/templates)

debug.description: When enabled, additional debug information will be generated.

disable_signup.description: Indicates whether or not to allow user sign-ups to your application

fields_map.description: If you're configuring a SAML enterprise connection for a non-standard PingFederate Server, you must update the attribute mappings.

import_mode.description: Indicates whether or not you have a legacy user store and want to gradually migrate those users to the Auth0 user store

metadata_url.description: Url of the document for saml connection expressed in xml

metadata_xml.description: XML content of the document for saml

non_persistent_attrs.description: If there are user fields that should not be stored in Auth0 databases due to privacy reasons, you can add them to the DenyList here

password_policy.description: Indicates level of password strength to enforce during authentication. A strong password policy will make it difficult, if not improbable, for someone to guess a password through either manual or automated means. Options include `none`, `low`, `fair`, `good`, `excellent`

protocol_binding.description: The SAML Response Binding: how the SAML token is received by Auth0 from IdP

request_template.description: Template that formats the SAML request.

requires_username.description: Indicates whether or not the user is required to provide a username in addition to an email address

set_user_root_attributes.description: Determines whether the 'name', 'given_name', 'family_name', 'nickname', and 'picture' attributes can be independently updated when using an external IdP. Possible values are 'on_each_login' (default value, it configures the connection to automatically update the root attributes from the external IdP with each user login. When this setting is used, root attributes cannot be independently updated), 'on_first_login' (configures the connection to only set the root attributes on first login, allowing them to be independently updated thereafter)

should_trust_email_verified_connection.description: Choose how Auth0 sets the email_verified field in the user profile.

sign_in_endpoint.description: SAML single login URL for the connection.

sign_out_endpoint.description: SAML single logout URL for the connection.

sign_saml_request.description: When enabled, the SAML authentication request will be signed.

signing_cert.description: X.509 signing certificate (encoded in PEM or CER) you retrieved from the IdP, Base64-encoded

user_id_attribute.description: Attribute in the SAML token that will be mapped to the user_id property in Auth0.

block.description: Configuration settings for password complexity
Configuration settings for the password dictionary check, which does not allow passwords that are part of the password dictionary
Configuration settings for the password history that is maintained for each user to prevent the reuse of passwords

Configuration settings for the password personal info check, which does not allow passwords that contain any part of the user's personal data, including user's name, username, nickname, user_metadata.name, user_metadata.first, user_metadata.last, user's email, or firstpart of the user's email
Specifies the min and max values of username length
Validation of the minimum and maximum values allowed for a user to have as username
Configuration settings for connection options

With Auth0, you can define sources of users, otherwise known as connections, 
which may include identity providers (such as Google or LinkedIn), databases, 
or passwordless authentication methods. This resource allows you to configure and manage connections to be used with
your clients and users.

primary.description: Indicates whether or not this is a primary domain

status.description: Configuration status for the custom domain. Options include `disabled`, `pending`, `pending_verification`, and `ready`

type.description: Provisioning type for the custom domain. Valid options are: auth0_managed_certs, self_managed_certs

block.description:
With Auth0, you can use a custom domain to maintain a consistent user experience. 
This resource allows you to create and manage a custom domain within your Auth0 tenant.

default_from_address.description: Email address to use as `from` when no other address specified

enabled.description: Whether the provider is enabled (`true`) or disabled (`false`)

region.description: Mailgun region. If set must be `eu`

block.description: Configuration for the mailgun email integration
Configuration for the mandrill email integration
Configuration for the sendgrid email integration

secret_access_key.description: Secret Access key. It's not advisable to store it in clear

block.description: Configuration for the Aws ses email integration
Configuration for the generic SMTP email integration

region.description: Sparkpost region. If set must be `eu`

block.description: Configuration for the sparkpost email integration

With Auth0, you can have standard welcome, password reset, 
and account verification email-based workflows built right into Auth0. 
This resource allows you to configure email providers so you can route all emails that are part of Auth0's
authentication workflows through the supported high-volume email service of your choice.

body.description: Body of the email template. You can include [common variables](https://auth0.com/docs/email/templates#common-variables)

enabled.description: Indicates whether or not the template is enabled

from.description: Email address to use as the sender. You can include [common variables](https://auth0.com/docs/email/templates#common-variables)

result_url.description: URL to redirect the user to after a successful action. [Learn more](https://auth0.com/docs/email/templates#configuring-the-redirect-to-url)

subject.description: Subject line of the email. You can include [common variables](https://auth0.com/docs/email/templates#common-variables)

syntax.description: Syntax of the template body. You can use either text or HTML + Liquid syntax

url_lifetime_in_seconds.description: Number of seconds during which the link within the email will be valid

block.description:
With Auth0, you can have standard welcome, password reset, 
and account verification email-based workflows built right into Auth0. 

This resource allows you to configure email templates to customize the look, feel, 
and sender identities of emails sent by Auth0. Used in conjunction with configured email providers.

trigger_id.description: Execution stage of this rule. Can be post-login, credentials-exchange, pre-user-registration, post-user-registration, post-change-password, or send-phone-message

display_name.description: How will the action be displayed on dashboard ui

id.description: Action ID. Either id or name must be specified (if both, id has priority)

name.description: Action name. Either id or name must be specified (if both, id has priority)

block.description: The list of triggers that this action supports. At this time, an action can only target a single trigger at a time

Update the actions that are bound (i.e. attached) to a trigger. Once an action is created and deployed, it must be
attached (i.e. bound) to a trigger so that it will be executed as part of a flow.

The order in which the actions are provided will determine the order in which they are executed.

Multi-factor Authentication works by requiring additional factors during the login process to
prevent unauthorized access. 

With this resource you can configure some of the options available for MFA.

dependencies.description: Dependencies of this hook used by webtask server

enabled.description: Whether the hook is enabled, or disabled

script.description: Code to be executed when this hook runs

secrets.description: The secrets associated with the hook

trigger_id.description: Execution stage of this rule. Can be credentials-exchange, pre-user-registration, post-user-registration, post-change-password, or send-phone-message

block.description:
Hooks are secure, self-contained functions that allow you to customize the behavior of Auth0 when executed for selected
extensibility points of the Auth0 platform. Auth0 invokes Hooks during runtime to execute your custom Node.js code.

Depending on the extensibility point, you can use Hooks with Database Connections and/or Passwordless Connections.

type.description: Type of the log stream, which indicates the sink provider

aws_partner_event_source.description: Name of the Partner Event Source to be used with AWS. Generally generated by Auth0 and passed to AWS so this should generally be an output attribute.

azure_partner_topic.description: Name of the Partner Topic to be used with Azure.  Generally should not be specified.

azure_resource_group.description: The Azure EventGrid resource group which allows you to manage all Azure assets within one subscription

azure_subscription_id.description: The unique alphanumeric string that identifies your Azure subscription

datadog_region.description: The Datadog region. Must be one of `eu` or `us`

http_authorization.description: Sent in the HTTP `Authorization` header with each request

http_content_format.description: HTTP Content Format can be `JSONLINES`, `JSONARRAY` or `JSONOBJECT`

http_content_type.description: The ContentType header to send over HTTP.  Common value is `application/json`

http_custom_headers.description: Additional HTTP headers to be included as part of the HTTP request

http_endpoint.description: The HTTP endpoint to send streaming logs

splunk_secure.description: This toggle should be turned off when using self-signed certificates

sumo_source_address.description: Generated URL for your defined HTTP source in Sumo Logic for collecting streaming data from Auth0

block.description: With this resource, you can manage your Auth0 log streams

identifier_first.description: Whether identifier first is enabled or not

universal_login_experience.description: Which login experience to use. Options include `classic` and `new`

block.description:
With this resource, you can manage your Auth0 prompts, 
including choosing the login experience version

allow_offline_access.description: Indicates whether or not refresh tokens can be issued for this resource server

enforce_policies.description: Indicates whether or not authorization polices are enforced

identifier.description: Unique identifier for the resource server. Used as the audience parameter for authorization calls. Can not be changed once set

name.description: Friendly name for the resource server. Cannot include `<` or `>` characters

signing_alg.description: Algorithm used to sign JWTs. Options include `HS256` and `RS256`

signing_secret.description: Secret used to sign tokens when using symmetric algorithms (HS256)

skip_consent_for_verifiable_first_party_.description: Indicates whether or not to skip user consent for applications flagged as first party

token_dialect.description: Dialect of access tokens that should be issued for this resource server. Options include `access_token` or `access_token_authz` (includes permissions)

token_lifetime.description: Number of seconds during which access tokens issued for this resource server from the token endpoint remain valid

token_lifetime_for_web.description: Number of seconds during which access tokens issued for this resource server via implicit or hybrid flows remain valid. Cannot be greater than the `token_lifetime` value

value.description: Name of the permission (scope). Examples include `read:appointments` or `delete:appointments`

block.description: List of permissions (scopes) used by this resource server
With this resource, you can set up APIs that can be consumed from your authorized applications

resource_server_identifier.description: Unique identifier for the resource server

block.description: Configuration settings for permissions (scopes) attached to the role

With this resource, you can created and manage collections of permissions that can be assigned to users, which are otherwise known as roles. Permissions (scopes) are created on auth0_resource_server, then associated with roles and optionally, users using this resource

enabled.description: Indicates whether the rule is enabled

name.description: Name of the rule. May only contain alphanumeric characters, spaces, and hyphens. May neither start nor end with hyphens or spaces

order.description: Order in which the rule executes relative to other rules. Lower-valued rules execute first

script.description: Code to be executed when the rule runs

block.description:
With Auth0, you can create custom Javascript snippets that run in a secure, 
isolated sandbox as part of your authentication pipeline, which are otherwise known as rules.

This resource allows you to create and manage rules.

You can create global variable for use with rules by using the auth0_rule_config resource.

key.description: Key for a rules configuration variable

value.description: Case-sensitive. Value for a rules configuration variable

block.description: With Auth0, you can create custom Javascript snippets that run in a secure, isolated sandbox as part of your authentication pipeline, which are otherwise known as rules. This resource allows you to create and manage variables that are available to all rules via Auth0's global configuration object. Used in conjunction with configured rules

allowed_logout_urls.description: URLs that Auth0 may redirect to after logout

default_directory.description: Name of the connection to be used for Password Grant exchanges. Options include `auth0-adldap`, `ad`, `auth0`, `email`, `sms`, `waad`, and `adfs`

enabled_locales.description: Supported locales for the user interface. The first locale in the list will be used to set the default locale

idle_session_lifetime.description: Number of hours during which a session can be inactive before the user must log in again

picture_url.description: String URL of logo to be shown for the tenant. Recommended size is 150px x 150px. If no URL is provided, the Auth0 logo will be used

sandbox_version.description: Selected sandbox version for the extensibility environment, which allows you to use custom scripts to extend parts of Auth0's functionality

session_lifetime.description: Number of hours during which a session will stay valid

support_email.description: Support email address for authenticating users

enabled.description: Indicates whether or not to use the custom change password page

html.description: HTML format with supported Liquid syntax. Customized content of the change password page

block.description: Configuration settings for change password page

html.description: HTML format with supported Liquid syntax. Customized content of the error page

show_log_link.description: Indicates whether or not to show the link to logs as part of the default error page

url.description: URL to redirect to when an error occurs rather than showing the default error page

block.description: Configuration settings for error pages

change_pwd_flow_v1.description: Indicates whether or not to use the older v1 change password flow. Not recommended except for backward compatibility

disable_clickjack_protection_headers.description: Indicated whether or not classic Universal Login prompts include additional security headers to prevent clickjacking

enable_apis_section.description: Indicates whether or not the APIs section is enabled for the tenant

enable_client_connections.description: Indicates whether or not all current connections should be enabled when a new client is created

enable_custom_domain_in_emails.description: Indicates whether or not the tenant allows custom domains in emails

enable_dynamic_client_registration.description: Indicates whether or not the tenant allows dynamic client registration

enable_legacy_logs_search_v2.description: Indicates whether or not to use the older v2 legacy logs search

enable_pipeline2.description: Indicates whether or not advanced API Authorization scenarios are enabled

enable_public_signup_user_exists_error.description: Indicates whether or not the public sign up process shows a user_exists error if the user already exists

universal_login.description: Indicates whether or not the tenant uses universal login

block.description: Configuration settings for tenant flags

enabled.description: Indicates whether or not to use the custom change password page

html.description: HTML format with supported Liquid syntax. Customized content of the change password page

block.description: Configuration settings for the Guardian MFA page

With this resource, you can manage Auth0 tenants, including setting logos and support contact information, setting error pages, and configuring default tenant behaviors.

~> Auth0 does not currently support creating tenants through the Management API. Therefore this resource can only manage an existing tenant created through the Auth0 dashboard.

Auth0 does not currently support adding/removing extensions on tenants through their API. The Auth0 dashboard must be used to add/remove extensions.
With this resource, you can manage user identities, including resetting passwords, and creating, provisioning, blocking, and deleting users
